<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 279, 170, 290]]<|/det|> # PHYSICS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 415, 311]]<|/det|> Paper 5 Planning, Analysis and Evaluation <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 339, 415, 351]]<|/det|> Candidates answer on the Question Paper. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 359, 367, 370]]<|/det|> No Additional Materials are required. <|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 392, 388, 404]]<|/det|> # READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 419, 718, 431]]<|/det|> Write your Centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 325, 446]]<|/det|> Write in dark blue or black pen. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 450, 503, 462]]<|/det|> You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 466, 504, 477]]<|/det|> Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 481, 380, 492]]<|/det|> DO **NOT** WRITE IN ANY BARCODES. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 508, 256, 519]]<|/det|> Answer **all** questions. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 535, 359, 547]]<|/det|> Electronic calculators may be used. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 551, 766, 563]]<|/det|> You may lose marks if you do not show your working or if you do not use appropriate units. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 577, 605, 588]]<|/det|> At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 592, 758, 604]]<|/det|> The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 73, 96, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 813, 90]]<|/det|>
A student is investigating how the boiling point of a salt solution varies with pressure.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 104, 917, 136]]<|/det|>
It is suggested that the relationship between the Celsius temperature \(\theta\) at which the water of the solution starts to boil and the air pressure \(P\) is

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[462, 149, 539, 166]]<|/det|>
\[\theta = k\sigma P^q\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 180, 644, 197]]<|/det|>
where \(\sigma\) is the density of the solution and \(k\) and \(q\) are constants.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 211, 713, 243]]<|/det|>
Design a laboratory experiment to test the relationship between \(\theta\) and \(P\). Explain how your results could be used to determine values for \(k\) and \(q\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 257, 917, 289]]<|/det|>
You should draw a diagram, on page 3, showing the arrangement of your equipment. In your account you should pay particular attention to

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 304, 400, 320]]<|/det|>
· the procedure to be followed,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 327, 415, 342]]<|/det|>
· the measurements to be taken,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 350, 352, 365]]<|/det|>
· the control of variables,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 373, 355, 387]]<|/det|>
· the analysis of the data,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 394, 446, 409]]<|/det|>
· any safety precautions to be taken.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 73, 918, 107]]<|/det|>
A student is investigating the electric potential near a charged metal sphere. The sphere is suspended from the ceiling as shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[200, 112, 845, 355]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 377, 532, 394]]<|/det|>
<pre>Fig. 2.1

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 408, 917, 441]]<|/det|>
A flame probe is used to measure the potential \(V\) at a distance \(L\) from the surface of the sphere. The experiment is repeated for different distances from the sphere.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 454, 571, 471]]<|/det|>
It is suggested that \(V\) and \(L\) are related by the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[435, 479, 565, 511]]<|/det|>
\[V = \frac{Q}{4\pi\epsilon_0(L + a)}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 516, 918, 549]]<|/det|>
where \(Q\) is the charge on the sphere, \(a\) is the radius of the sphere and \(\epsilon_0\) is the permittivity of free space.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 560, 148, 580]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 558, 650, 588]]<|/det|>
A graph is plotted of \(\frac{1}{V}\) on the \(y\)-axis against \(L\) on the \(x\)-axis.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 593, 641, 610]]<|/det|>
Determine expressions for the gradient and the \(y\)-intercept.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[495, 794, 915, 811]]<|/det|>
<form>gradient = ............................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[477, 825, 915, 842]]<|/det|>
<form>y-intercept = .........................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 841, 920, 859]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 73, 148, 90]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 477, 90]]<|/det|> Values of \(L\) and \(V\) are given in Fig. 2.2. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[219, 103, 778, 349]]<|/det|>
\(L/m\)\(V/kV\)\(\frac {1}{V}/10^{-3}V^{-1}\)
0.0181.25 ± 0.05
0.0361.05 ± 0.05
0.0530.90 ± 0.03
0.0680.80 ± 0.03
0.0890.70 ± 0.02
0.1130.60 ± 0.02
<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 361, 533, 378]]<|/det|> 
Fig. 2.2

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 384, 598, 415]]<|/det|>

Calculate and record values of \(\frac{1}{V}/10^{-3}V^{-1}\) in Fig. 2.2.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 416, 479, 448]]<|/det|>

Include the absolute uncertainties in \(\frac{1}{V}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 420, 920, 440]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 450, 525, 479]]<|/det|>
Plot a graph of \(\frac{1}{V}/10^{-3}V^{-1}\) against \(L/m\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 481, 396, 508]]<|/det|>

gradient = ........................................................................ [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 305, 917, 337]]<|/det|>
Using your answers to (a), (c)(iii) and (c)(iv), determine the values of \(a\) and \(Q\). Include an appropriate unit for \(Q\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 351, 437, 368]]<|/det|>
